title: Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2008
text:
The Department of Health and Human Services Appropriations Act of 2008 or the HHS-Labor-Education Appropriations Bill () is a <a href="Bill%20%28proposed%20law%29">bill</a> introduced in the <a href="U.S.%20House%20of%20Representatives">House of Representatives</a> during the <a href="110th%20United%20States%20Congress">110th United States Congress</a> by Rep. <a href="David%20Obey">David Obey</a>.
<a href="George%20W.%20Bush">President Bush</a> vetoed the act because of the cost and because it would ban the use of childhood flu vaccines that contain <a href="thimerosal">thimerosal</a>, a mercury-based preservative that has been alleged to cause <a href="autism">autism</a>.
Status.
The bill passed the House of Representatives and the <a href="U.%20S.%20Senate">U. S. Senate</a>. It was vetoed by President Bush on November 13, 2007. The House failed to achieve a two-thirds majority to override the president's veto by two votes on a 277–141 vote.
